Hello @WillAyd! Thanks for updating the PR.















Cheers ! There are no PEP8 issues in this Pull Request. :beers:

Would it be an idea to explicitly split the files in readers and writers? The openpyxl writer file is already pretty large by itself, and as I am working on a reader it will get even larger. Even the _base.py is prretty large, and there is very little shared code nor shared concern between the reader and writer functions.

Yea I thought about that too but I think the reader and writer modules would just be pretty large in that case. What other modules would you have think of besides those two?

Sent from my iPhone

> On Feb 4, 2019, at 10:06 PM, Thijs Damsma <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> Would it be an idea to explicitly split the files in readers and writers? The openpyxl writer file is already pretty large by itself, and as I am working on a reader it will get even larger. Even the _base.py is prretty large, and there is very little shared code nor shared concern between the reader and writer functions.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

I think I wasn't clear, I mean split by library (openpyx, xlrd, whatever) as you propse, and additionally also split by read/write functionality. So that gives something like:
```
_base_reader.py
_base_writer.py
_openpyxl_reader.py
_openpyxl_writer.py
_xlrd_reader.py
_xlsxwriter_writer.py
etc
```

While I am writing this out this doesn't look so nice anymore. Other options:

- A reader and writer submodule in the excel module?
-  Reverse the names like so:

```
_reader_base.py
_reader_openpyxl.py
_reader_xlrd.py
_writer_base.py
_writer_openpyxl.py
_writer_xlsxwriter.py
etc
```

> I mean split by library (openpyx, xlrd, whatever) as you propse, and additionally also split by read/write functionality. So that gives something like:

xref #24749

The only library that can both read and write is openpyxl, so splitting by reader/writer is superfluous for most libraries here. Not against doing it if that's the ultimate structure desired by everyone but at the moment I don't think that adds much value or would drastically minimize anything, save splitting _base and _openpyxl into two more modules.
@WillAyd yep agree about readers/writers. do we have an issue for this split (or just the comment)?
No issue just comment. Happy to open one

You bring up very valid questions but why would you want to tackle them in this PR? Really trying to limit this to pure copy / paste of code blocks so it doesn’t get out of hand just like we have done on almost any other similar change

> On Feb 6, 2019, at 5:26 PM, gfyoung <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> @gfyoung commented on this pull request.
>

> > @@ -0,0 +1,16 @@

> I'm not sure I follow - given that +/- 2000 line diff from git, what diff are you trying to minimize?

big moves like this should have almost no changes to the actual code

diffs
@WillAyd, any chance you can resolve the conflicts and get this merged so I can continue working on #25092?
